Posts.Content: Hi, I had my surgery in oct/Dec 2013, and  RT in March 2014, I started using a crystal product called PitRock, which I got from boots, recommended to my by my breast unit,  it really works, even in the summer.  I am still using the same one so it last for ages.  I think amazon have it as well.  Good luck. Janet xx
Posts.Title: Deodorant

Posts.Content: Hi Denise, I agree with the others, yesterday when I heard about the new royal baby I felt so happy with everything, then I saw the news about Rio Ferdinand's poor wife and I just cried - 34! and so quick, how can that be, I can relate to her poor children, my mum died when I was 9 of BC, so when I read about ladies who don't make it , it knocks me back so much.  I also think that every ache and pain is something major, I wish I could stop this, but I suppose it is normal now to think like  this. june 11th is not so far away, but so many ladies have pains and problems with these treatments, hopefully your oncologist will put your mind at rest. take care and enjoy the bank holiday weekend . Janet xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Hi all, Just heard Tiggy Walker on Jeremy VIne show talking about her book, unplanned journey, which documents in pictures her treatment.  what an inspiration!  I will be putting her book on my xmas list from santa!
Posts.Title: unplanned journey

Posts.Content: sorry my her2 was negative  so you maybe slighty different in your combination drugs on chemo xxx
Posts.Title: What chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, My diagnosis and treatment was the same as yours, but  I was grade 3 2cm tumour,  I then got a chemo score of 3.5 which was in a 'grey area', so they offered me a genetic test called 'oncotype DX , which is sent over to California, and they test 21 sets of genes in the tumour sample.  You then get a score and the hospital decide if you need chemo.  Luckly for me i did not need the dreaded chemo, but they said it would have been  6 of the FEC combination of drugs.  I did have to pay for the test as it was not on the NHS funding, but I was glad i did not have the chemo unnecessarily. Good luck and merry christmas Janet xx
Posts.Title: What chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Kathy, brilliant news you have been funded, now for 3 weeks wait!  they normally e mail the results over to oncology here, wait til you see it - pure rocket science!  I hope your score is low like mine was. take care love Janet xx
Posts.Title: My test was funded!

Posts.Content: Hi Kathy, Great news! So  pleased for you, I had a gut feeling you would be okay.  Good luck for the rads, just clear your diary and pace yyourself for the 3 to 4  weeks of treatment Take care and enjoy the weekend. Janet X
Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx results ...

Posts.Content: Hi all, I don't  post very often now, but i read the daily e mail from the group.  I am from the class of 2013, and today had my 3 year check with the surgical doctor.  she said that i was now being discharged from them and oncology, and would just have my annual mammogram as normal for the next 3 years.  Also I will continue to take tamoxifen for the next 2 years, being 5 in total, and they would assess then if i need continue for a further 5 years.  she said that if i had a problem or suspect anything, i can call my bcn who will arrange for me to see a doctor immediately.  This process would free up appointments thus only seeing a doctor if i was concerned with any changes.  i have heard of this from others on this site, and i wanted to see if anyone else is in this situation.  On the one hand i am happy that i have been discharged, but its nice to have that 'comfort blanket' of regular appointments! Janet x
Posts.Title: new hospital procedures for regular check ups

Posts.Content: I was the same, I had no symptoms, mine was picked up on my first routine mammogram, so even though I know what to look for, if you have no symptoms I suppose you just have to make sure you get the yearly mammograms. My breast unit are very good at calling back if you had a problem, so I will hold onto that I think . Xx
Posts.Title: new hospital procedures for regular check ups

Posts.Content: hi yes I agree!   I didn't realise the nurse had even  done it!  - your boob will look like a smurf for about a year though after op! Good luck for op tomorrow  Janet xx
Posts.Title: radioactive injection

Posts.Content: Has anyone else heard that new Ed Sheeran/ rudimental  song Bloodstream?  it goes on about chemicals in his bloodstream, and sings " tell  me when it kicks in! " - or am I being paranoid? -do we really need a song that sounds like Chemo treatment? aggh!!!
Posts.Title: yet another cancer song?

Posts.Content: Hi Millie 99 I too did not have chemo, and my onco score was 22, so I was very apprehensive on my first mammogram back in December 2014, I am now due my 3rd this December, but I remember my oncologist saying to me that it was highly unlikely I would have a problem on my first mammogram, because it was so close to the treatment ending ( I finished radiotherapy in March 2014).  I still feel apprehensive at this time of year when my mammogram is due, thinking the same as you -  should I have had chemo? but  I think all of us are worried about reocurrance so it is  natural you are worried  .  Please let us know your results, and I wish you good luck. Love Janet x
Posts.Title: 1st mammogram/checkup after treatment. One year down the line.

Posts.Content: hi this is very similar to the oncotype dx i had done last year .  My test was about the same cost, but the test was done in America, so this is good that it is tested in London, thus cutting down the 3 week wait for the results to come back. Janet
Posts.Title: Interesting news

Posts.Content: Blimey that's a massive increase in costs.  Genomic health did offer interest free credit over different periods of time if that helps you, they did give me a bit of  a discount for paying in full though.  I think it was up to 2 years to pay it off, hopefully they still offer this service.  Best wishes to you. Janet x
Posts.Title: Interesting news

Posts.Content: Hi Kathy, i had the oncotyp dx done in January 14 because I was borderline chemo,  and I matched all the criteria for the test, stage 1 ,grade 3 , 2cm tumor, er+,her neg.  the test took 3 weeks to do cos the sample had to go to America, I was in the intermediate group cos it was a grade 3 but my score came back as 22, which was at the bottom of the range so I didn't need chemo. I paid 2,500 private, but I understand now the nhs are funding it to be done so check with your oncologist. good luck  janet xx
Posts.Title: Interesting news

Posts.Content: hi I have been on tamoxifen for 18 months now, and have had minimal side effects, Periods stopped back in July 2014 but i am 52! , and i occasionaly get a 'bit hot' , and i have a bit of joint pain in my fingers, but i had that before the tamoxifen but it is a bit more painful now, but nothing i cant handle.  there are a lot of ladies on it who do suffer, but there is also some of us without too many problems.  I read in the paper yesterday that scientists have proved that coffee with tamoxifen stops returning cancer!  woo hoo i can have caffeine again!   every cloud...... take care and good luck with the tamoxifen Janet xx
Posts.Title: Good news!!

Posts.Content: Hi Kargus Hope you are well,  I also got asked to take part in this trial, but I declined it because you could be in the group that only has mammograms 2 yearly and I feel better for having mine yearly for 5  years.  Dont know about you but i sort of have this annual mammogram as my safety net.   I have 2 more left until i get to the magical 5 years!  I also get asked to take part in lots of trials- healthy lifestyles etc, but I just want to put it behind me and just have the mammograms so I always say no. Hope this helps you decide, I would say that you dont get a choice which group you are put in, it is random which put me off from the start! Love janet
Posts.Title: Mammo 50

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, welcome to the best support you can get, I too had a grade 3 2cm picked up on my first mammogram at 51, I had no symptoms at all - so you can imagine how shocked and scared I was. I had a lumpectomy and radio therapy.  My oncologist said that so many tumours are picked up on this screening, so they are caught early enough, I am grateful every day for that mammogram saving my life.  Herceptin i think is a hormone drug, I take tamoxifen, it depends on your tumour , if its positive or negative, or estrogen receptive as to which drug you take. Good luck with your operation,  you will get a lot of support on this site - just don't google anything! Take care Janet x
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O
